questions.question: Which of the following inhibits the rate-limiting enzyme in catecholamine synthesis?
An asthmatic patient has been taking a salbutamol inhaler to control his wheezing episodes.Which of the following is not an effect seen on stimulation of the receptor involved?
questions.explanation: Salbutamol is a short-acting, selective ẞ2-adrenergic receptor agonist used in the treatment ofasthma and COPD. ẞ2 receptors mediate the stimulation of lipolysis (not inhibition).Adrenergic control of adipose tissue:• Stimulation of lipolysis - ° 1, B1, B2, and ẞ3 receptors• Inhibition of lipolysis - ° 2Adrenergic receptActionsor° 1receptor2receptorẞireceptor-Vasoconstriction of large arteriolesGenito-urinary smoothmuscle contraction Uterinemuscles contractionMydriasis by contraction of radial muscles of the irisIncrease secretion of glandsGastrointestinal relaxationAutoregulatory in the sympathetic systemVasoconstrictionof precapillary arterioles in skeletal muscles Decrease insulin synthesisIncreased rhythmicity and force of contraction of the heartIncreased renin secretion - JG cells in the kidney101Adrenergic receptorẞ2receptorActionsẞ3receptorSmooth muscle relaxation: vasodilation, bronchodilation Uterine muscle relaxationStimulation oflipolysis Increased insulin secretionIncreased hepaticgluconeogenesis IncreasedmuscleglycogenolysisStimulation of lipolysis Relaxation of detrusor

questions.question: Which of the following statements most appropriately describes the vasomotor reversal ofDale?

options.A: Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
options.B: Blockade of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
options.C: Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by blockade of beta 2
options.D: Stimulation of beta 1 followed by blockade of beta 2

questions.explanation: Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha (° 1) followed by stimulation of beta (ẞ2)receptors.Normally, a high dose of epinephrine injected produces an ° 1-mediated rise in BP followed by aẞ2-mediated fall in BP.Administration of epinephrine after administration of ° -blockers produces only a fall in BP. Thisis because the° -mediated response is abolished and hence, only the ẞ-mediated response is seen,resulting in a fall in BP. This phenomenon is called the vasomotor reversal of Dale. This was firstdemonstrated by Sir H.H.Dale.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs when administered would lead to a biphasic reaction on bloodpressure?
questions.explanation: Biphasic reaction on blood pressure is seen with the administration of adrenaline. The BP initiallyrises followed by a fall in BP.Adrenaline acts on 1, 2, B1, B2, and ẞ3 receptors.° 1 - present in blood vessels - causes vasoconstriction - increases BP.ẞ2-- present in blood vessels causes vasodilatation - decreases BP.At higher concentrations of adrenaline, alpha action predominates and hence a rise in BP is seen.Therefore an increase in BP is seen with IV administration of adrenaline.Due to rapid metabolism and uptake, the concentration of adrenaline decreases, and the ẞ2 actionpredominates. Hence a decrease in BP is seen. This is referred to as the biphasic reaction.Adrenergic drReceptors it acts onugAdrenaline1+ ° 2+ẞ1+ ẞ2+ weak ẞ3actionNoradrenaline° 1+ 2+ẞ1+ ẞ3butno ẞ2action102Adrenergic drReceptors it acts onugIsoprenalineẞ1+ ẞ2+ B3butno ° action

questions.question: Which of the following would not increase with slow IV infusion of adrenaline?
questions.explanation: Slow intravenous infusion of adrenaline results in a significant increase in systolic blood pressurewith minimal effect on diastolic pressure.Mean blood pressure and pulse pressure increase. This is because of the increased systolicpressure coupled with decreased, unchanged, or an insignificant increase in diastolic pressure.At lower concentrations of adrenaline, vascular ẞ2 receptors are more sensitive than ° receptors,hence peripheral resistance decreases.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.A: IV noradrenaline increases systolic and diastolic BP and causes tachycardia
options.B: IV adrenaline increases systolic, decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia
options.C: Dopamine increases peripheral resistance and improves renal perfusion
options.D: IV isoproterenol increases systolic and decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia

questions.explanation: IV noradrenaline increases systolic and diastolic BP but is unlikely to cause tachycardia.IV noradrenaline acts on ° 1, ° 2, and 31 receptors:• ° 1- vasoconstriction - Increases DBP.•ẞ1 - increases heart rate and contractility - Increases SBP.• This increases mean arterial pressure which causes a reflex vagal activity that decreases the heartrate leading to bradycardia.IV adrenaline acts on ° 1, ° 2, B1, B2, and ẞ3 receptors:• ẞ1 - - increases SBP, tachycardia.• DBP - either ẞ2 - decrease DBP, ° 1 - increase DBP or ° 1+ẞ2 - no change.Dopamine acts on ẞ1,° 1, and D1 receptors:• D1 - low concentrations - causes vasodilatation thus improving renal perfusion•ẞ1- positive inotropic effect - increases SBP.• ° 1 - higher infusion rates - causes vasoconstriction and increases peripheral resistanceIV isoproterenol is a non-selective ẞ receptor agonist:•ẞ1- increases SBP•ẞ2- vasodilatation - decreases DBP• ẞ1- tachycardia

questions.question: A patient in low output cardiogenic shock is being treated with dobutamine. Which of thefollowing is true about the drug?

options.B: Acts on D1 and D2 receptors
options.D: Has no effect on coronary circulation

questions.explanation: 103Dobutamine decreases peripheral resistance minimally.Clinically, dobutamine increases cardiac output by selectively increasing myocardial contractilityand promotes coronary vasodilation. This is associated with a mild decrease in total peripheralvascular resistance, which is mediated by the reflex withdrawal of sympathetic tone to thevasculature.Dobutamine has a t1/2 of 2 minutes. It resembles dopamine but no action is seen on dopaminereceptors.Renal circulation is variably affected depending upon the sympathetic tone of the patient.

questions.question: During a rotation in the acute medical ward, you observe a patient in cardiogenic shock beingstarted on a low-dose dopamine infusion. Which of the following would you expect to increasein this patient?93
questions.explanation: At lower doses (< 2 µg/kg), dopamine only stimulates dopamine receptors in renal vasculature,causing increased urine output.As the dose increases (2-5 µg/kg), additional cardiac stimulant action (ẞ1) is also seen.At very high doses (5-15 µg/kg), vasoconstriction (° 1) is additionally seen.

questions.question: A stress ECHO has to be done for a 56-year-old COPD patient with high suspicion of coronaryartery disease. Which of the following drugs can be used to perform this test?
questions.explanation: Dobutamine is used to perform a stress test.Stress echocardiography is primarily done for the evaluation of myocardial ischemia. The basicprinciple is to increase cardiac stress (either with exercise or with a drug) in a controlled fashion,to aid with the identification and localization of ischemic areas (by detecting new or worseningwall motion abnormalities).Performing stress echocardiography with a pharmacologic agent such as dobutamine allows forsimulation of increased heart rate and increased myocardial physiologic demands in patients whomay be unable to exercise due to musculoskeletal or pulmonary comorbidities.Dobutamine causes cardiac stress by acting on ẞ1-adrenergic receptors to increase cardiaccontractility and heart rate, and on ẞ2-adrenergic receptors to cause peripheral vasodilatation. Itis preferred over vasodilators used in stress echo tests such as adenosine, dipyridamole, andregadenoson (adenosine derivative).

questions.question: You notice fenoldopam mentioned on the drug chart of an elderly male patient admitted inthe ICU. What condition is he most likely being treated for?
questions.explanation: Fenoldopam is primarily indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies. It is a D1agonist at peripheral D1 receptors and acts as a rapid-acting vasodilator.Drugs used in a hypertensive emergency are:• Nitroprusside• Nicardipine104• Labetalol• Hydralazine• Esmolol•Nitroglycerine•Phentolamine• Fenoldopam

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indirectly acting sympathomimetic?
questions.explanation: Oxymetazoline is a direct-acting non-selective ° 1 and ° 2 receptor agonist.Amphetamine, methamphetamine, and tyramine are catecholamine releasing agents and areconsidered to be indirectly acting sympathomimetic agents.

questions.question: 94Following spinal anesthesia, the blood pressure of a patient started dropping. Your seniorasks you to administer a mixed-acting sympathomimetic. Which of the following loadedsyringes will you pick?
questions.explanation: Ephedrine is a mixed-acting sympathomimetic agent which can be used to manage hypotensionfollowing spinal anesthesia.Drugs that release norepinephrine and also directly activate receptors are called mixed-actingsympathomimetics.Ephedrine has a dual action:• Releasing agent: releases neurotransmitters from nerve endings.• Direct action on ° 1, ° 2, ẞ1, and ẞ2 receptors.The adrenergic agents are classified into three sub-groups:•Directly acting agents:• Selective agents - phenylephrine (° 1), clonidine (° 2), dobutamine (ẞ1), terbutaline (ẞ2).• Non-selective agents - oxymetazoline (° 1 + ° 2), isoproterenol (ẞ1 + ẞ2), epinephrine(° 1 + 2 +ẞ1 + ẞ2) norepinephrine (° 1 +° 2 +2 + ẞ1)• Mixed acting agents - ephedrine (° 1 +° 2 +ẞ1 + ẞ2 + catecholamine releasing agent)•Indirectly acting agents:• Catecholamine releasing agents amphetamine and tyramine•• Uptake inhibitor - cocaine-•MAO inhibitor - selegeline• COMT inhibitor entacapone105

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true about clonidine?

options.A: It acts on alpha 2 adrenergic receptors
options.B: Can result in rebound hypertension on abrupt withdrawal

questions.explanation: Clonidine is a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. It is not associated with CNS stimulation.It treats high blood pressure by stimulating presynaptic ° 2 receptors in the vasomotor center inthe brainstem. This binding has a sympatholytic effect, by suppressing the release ofnorepinephrine and other sympathomimetics.-Option A Clonidine is an alpha 2 receptor agonist that reduces central sympathetic outflow.Option B - Abrupt withdrawal after long-term therapy can result in rebound hypertension.Option D - Dry mouth and sedation are the major side effects of clonidine. It can also causeimpotency and constipation.

questions.question: You are administering clonidine intravenously to a patient. Which of the following effectswould you observe?

options.A: Prolonged rapid fall in blood pressure
options.B: Transient rise in blood pressure followed by a prolonged fall
options.C: Transient fall in blood pressure followed by a prolonged rise
options.D: Prolonged rapid rise in blood pressure

questions.explanation: Intravenous administration of clonidine results in a transient rise in blood pressure followed by aprolonged fall.° 2 receptors are present on the presynaptic as well as the postsynaptic ganglia. They are theautoreceptors of the sympathetic system.Clonidine is a directly acting ° 2 agonist. When it activates the postsynaptic ° 2 receptors invascular smooth muscle, there is a transient rise in the blood pressure. This is followed byactivation of central ° 2 receptors, which results in decreases the central sympathetic tone andcauses a prolonged fall in blood pressure.2 receptors are present postsynaptically in vascular walls and activation results in the sameaction as ° 1 stimulation i.e., vasoconstriction. But the major receptor that is responsible forvasoconstriction in vascular walls is the postsynaptic ° 1 receptor.

questions.question: In which of the following patients is therapy with an adrenergic-agonist not useful?

options.A: 50-year-old woman suffering from acute decompensated heart failure
options.B: 35-year-old man in septic shock with persistent hypotension

questions.explanation: Adrenergic agonists are not useful in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. Adrenergic antagonists(phentolamine) are used locally for vasodilation in erectile dysfunction as PIPE therapy(Phentolamine Induced Penile Erection).Adrenergic agonists are mainly sympathomimetic due to their action on peripheral vascular orpost-synaptic alpha receptors. However, certain adrenergic agonists (like clonidine) act as asympatholytic due to their predominant action on pre-synaptic ° 2 receptors which inhibits therelease of noradrenaline.Options A and B: In hypotensive states like shock and acute decompensated heart failure,short-term therapy with parenteral sympathomimetic drugs are indicated in treatment.Option C: Clonidine is an adrenergic agonist which acts on the pre-synaptic ° 2 receptor andis used in the treatment of hypertension.106

questions.question: A 22-week pregnant woman presents to the OPD for a routine check-up. On examination, herBP is 150/100 mmHg but she does not have a history of hypertension. You prescribemethyldopa to treat her. On which of the following receptors does this drug act?
questions.explanation: The given scenario suggests a diagnosis of gestational hypertension, for which methyldopa is used.It acts on 2 receptors.Methyldopa is a centrally acting ° 2-adrenergic receptor agonist that is converted intoalpha-methyl-norepinephrine. It decreases central sympathetic outflow, decreasing systemicvascular resistance without decreasing cardiac output.

questions.question: The following table gives BP values before and after administration of drug 'X'. What wouldbe the probable mechanism of action of drug 'X'?

options.D: ẞ1 agonist and ẞ2 agonistDRUG XSBP120150DBP80808068HR728698©MARROW

questions.explanation: The probable mechanism of action of drug 'X' is ẞ1 and ß2 agonism.According to the given table, systolic BP and heart rate is increased due to ẞ1 agonistic effect, anddiastolic BP is decreased by vasodilatation due to ẞ2 action.Option A: Action on ° 1 causes ↑ DBPOption B: Action on M2 causes ↓HR and action on M3 causes vasodilatation and reflex increasein HR. Hence there is no net effect on heart rateOption C: 1 antagonism causes vasodilatation and ↓ DBP. ẞ2 action causes vasodilatation andDBP

questions.question: Which of the following is not an alpha adrenoreceptor agonist?96
questions.explanation: Isoproterenol is a non-selective ẞ-receptor agonist with no action on ° -receptors.Clonidine, guanabenz, and guanfacine are ° 2 receptor agonists.

questions.question: Why is salbutamol preferred over adrenaline in the treatment of an asthmatic patient?
questions.explanation: Salbutamol is preferred over adrenaline in an asthmatic patient due to ẞ2 selectivity.This ẞ2 selectivity is relative and lost at higher concentrations. Around 40% of the beta receptorsare of ẞ2 type and their activation won't cause cardiac stimulation.Major adverse effects of non-selective ẞ-agonists are attributed to the stimulation of ẞ1 receptorsin the heart which result in tachyarrhythmias. Selective ẞ2 receptor agonists are introduced toovercome this major drawback.

questions.question: A 56-year-old man diagnosed with chronic bronchitis was prescribed a long-acting beta-2agonist. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation: Formoterol is a long-acting ẞ2 agonist (LABA).ẞ2 agonists are classified as:107•Short-acting ẞ2 receptor agonists (SABA):• Albuterol (Salbutamol)• Pirbuterol•Orciprenaline• Long-acting ẞ2 agonists (LABA):• Salmeterol• Formoterol• Ultra-long acting ẞ2 agonists (VLABA):• Indacaterol•• Olodaterol•Vilanterol• Carmoterol

questions.question: Which of the following beta 2 receptor agonists was developed specifically as a uterinerelaxant?
questions.explanation: Ritodrine was developed specifically as a uterine relaxant.Salbutamol, orciprenaline, and terbutaline can also be used as uterine relaxants but were initiallydeveloped as inhalational agents for asthma. ẞ2 agonists are associated with increased mortalityand are rarely used as uterine relaxants now.

questions.question: 97A child suffering from intermittent bronchial asthma is being treated with ẞ2 agonists. Whichof the following side effects would you not expect?

options.B: HypoglycemiaHypokalemiad) TachycardiaQuestion 23:A 4-year-old child on salbutamol is brought to the hospital with complaints of tremors. Whichof the following effects of the drug would explain this side effect?a) 1, 2, and 5b) 2 and 4

questions.explanation: ẞ2 agonists are associated with hyperglycemia probably due to ẞ2 receptor-mediatedglycogenolysis and glucagon release.Adverse effects of beta 2 agonists:• Hypokalemia - direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions• Tachycardia - reflex sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on ẞ2 receptors and directeffect on cardiac ẞ1 receptors (ẞ2 selectivity is lost at high concentrations)• Muscle tremors - direct effect on ẞ2 receptors in skeletal muscles and due to hypokalemia..HyperglycaemiaHyperlipidemia•• Tolerance - desensitization on long-term use

questions.question: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of salbutamol?
questions.explanation: Salbutamol in large doses can result in hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.Option A: Tachycardia due to reflex sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on ẞ2receptors and direct effect on cardiac ẞ1 receptors (ẞ2 selectivity is lost at high concentrations)Option B: Tolerance occurs due to desensitization on long-term useOption C: Hypokalemia due to direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions

questions.question: A 68-year-old man with Parkinson's disease was prescribed mirabegron to control hissymptoms of urinary urgency and incontinence. What is the mechanism of action of thisdrug?
questions.explanation: Mirabegron is a ẞ3 agonist used for the treatment of overactive bladder (OAB). Stimulation ofß3 receptors in detrusor muscle increases the bladder capacity and provides symptomatic relief inoveractive bladder.Antimuscarinic drugs are the mainstay of oral pharmacological treatment for OAB. It acts byinhibiting muscarinic receptor subtypes, M2 and M3 in the bladder. Both subtypes are expressedin multiple tissues, resulting in anticholinergic adverse events such as dry mouth, constipation,and cognitive impairment. These adverse effects are not seen with mirabegron as it acts viaadrenergic receptors.Mirabegron is a moderate inhibitor of CYP2D6. Hence, caution has to be exercised whenprescribing it along with CYP2D6 substrates such as metoprolol, desipramine, digoxin.

questions.question: What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock?
questions.explanation: Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment ofanaphylactic shock.For intravenous use, 1:1000 adrenaline must be further diluted to 1:10,000 and should be usedvery cautiously as slow bolus.There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by either inappropriate dosage ormisdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline. Hence, IM injection is preferred overintravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (lower risk ofcardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias).For intramuscular, subcutaneous, and inhalational (nebulization) routes of administration, 1:1000dilution can be used.109In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV use. The recommendeddose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of 1:10,000 solution IV administered every 3 to 5 minutesduring resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines.Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction toreduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics and to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.

questions.question: A patient was treated for septicemia with norepinephrine infusion. Which of the followingbest explains the benefit of this drug?
questions.explanation: The benefit of using noradrenaline in septicemia is that it increases the mean arterial bloodpressure. It acts as a powerful peripheral vasoconstrictor and inotrope.Noradrenaline causes a rise in both systolic BP and diastolic BP, resulting in a rise in the meanarterial blood pressure. This increases the organ perfusion in patients in septic shockor cardiogenic shock.Another advantage of noradrenaline is that it does so without causing tachycardia, which is oftena troublesome event with other inotropes in critical care.Options A and B: The rise in mean arterial pressure causes reflex bradycardia which is not a majorcontributor to the treatment of septic shock.Option C: Low-dose dopamine infusions and furosemide are used to increase urine output incritically ill patients.

questions.question: Match the following dilution of adrenaline and its use:
questions.explanation: Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml I.M. is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV route, and usedcautiously.Adrenaline in a concentration of 1: 50,000 to 1: 200,000 is added to local anesthetics for:•Reducing the systemic absorption•Prolonging the duration of action• Providing a more bloodless field for surgery1:1000 dilution can be used for the following routes of administration:• Intramuscular• Subcutaneous• Inhalational (nebulization)IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations andsafer (ie, lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventriculararrhythmias). There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by inappropriate dosageor misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline.110Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction toreduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics, to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.Note: The recommended dose of epinephrine is img = 10 mL of a 1:10,000 solution administeredIV every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines. For nebulization, 1:1000adrenaline is commonly used.111
